Was ist der Output des folgenden Codes? let x = 1+1 console.log(x) Copy 1 0 Submit
To follow along with this lecture you need python pandas the Dataset we are going to use: vgsales.csv info Please download the Dataset and follow along as you read this lecture
Dataframes in pandas are basically just tables. The most common way to create a Dataframe is by reading a csv file df = pd.read_csv('data.csv') Copy

To get a sense of what our Dataset looks like we can take a lot at the first rows with df.head() # returns the first 5 rows (5 is default) df.head() # You can also pass in the desired amount of rows # returns the first 10 rows df.head(10) Copy

If we are only interested in some of the columns we can select them as follows # select a single column genres = vgs['Genre'] publishers = vgs['Publisher'] # select multiple columns genres_and_publishers = vgs[['Genre', 'Publisher']] years_and_sales = vgs[['Year', 'Global_Sales']] # select rows based on condition games_from_2008 = vgs[vgs.Year == 2008] racing_games = vgs[vgs.Genre == 'Racing'] Copy info If you are unsure about the exact spelling of a column then you can always check the column names with print(df.columns) or print(list(df))

We can select a subset of rows if we pass in a boolean. If we want to chain multiple booleans together we have to use the bitwise operators &, |, ~, ^ instead of and, or, not # Select all Wii games wii_games = vgs[vgs.Platform == 'Wii'] # Select all Wii racing games wii_racing_games = vgs[(vgs.Platform == 'Wii') & (vgs.Genre == 'Racing')] Copy info You can also select Columns with the "dot Notation" E.g vgs.Name and vgs["Name"] are both equivalent.

If we want to select a subset of both rows and columns we could just chain the row and column selectors together # Select Publishers of Puzzle Games puzzle_publishers = vgs[vgs.Genre == 'Puzzle']['Publisher'] # Select Names of Playstation 2 Games ps2game_names = vgs[vgs.Platform == 'PS2']['Name'] Copy danger Do not do this because it can lead to chained assignments. Use DataFrame.loc instead If we use vgs.loc[<rowsSelector>, <columnsSelector>] our code would look like this # Select Publishers of Puzzle Games puzzle_publishers = vgs.loc[vgs.Genre == 'Puzzle', 'Publisher'] # Select Names of Playstation 2 Games ps2game_names = vgs.loc[vgs.Platform == 'PS2', 'Name'] Copy

Series.unique# # list all unique Publishers vgs['Publisher'].unique() # list all unique Genres vgs['Genre'].unique() Copy Series.value_counts# # Number of Games per Year vgs['Year'].value_counts() # Number of Games for each Genre vgs['Genre'].value_counts() Copy DataFrame.idxmax# # Year with the most Games vgs['Year'].value_counts().idxmax() Copy DataFrame.nlargest# # Select the 5 Publishers who have released the most games vgs['Publisher']value_counts().nlargest(5) # Select the 3 Years with most video games released vgs['Year']value_counts().nlargest(3) Copy
For more complex relations we can group the DataFrame by one or more columns. Copy

0) Find out which game has the greatest number of Platforms it was released on name = vgs.groupby('Name')['Platform'].nunique().idxmax() print(name) vgs.loc[vgs.Name == name, 'Platform'].unique() Copy 1.) Select the 5 most freqeuent Genres for the Publisher Nintendo nintendo = vgs.loc[vgs.Publisher == 'Nintendo', 'Genre'].value_counts().nlargest(5) Copy 2.) Select the 10 Publishers with the most unique games published vgs.groupby('Publisher')['Name'].nunique().nlargest(10) Copy 3.) Rank all Publishers by their total Global_Sales ranked = vgs.groupby('Publisher')['Global_Sales'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False) Copy
In the following, we load a world map from geopandas to a dataframe: # Load the world.shp data world = geopandas.read_file(geopandas.datasets.get_path('naturalearth_lowres')) Copy
documents.s: How to load a world map

documents.t: In the case of the map provided by ``naturalearth_lowres'', some language codes are missing. These can be added in the following way: world.loc[world['name'] == 'France', 'iso_a3'] = 'FRA' world.loc[world['name'] == 'Norway', 'iso_a3'] = 'NOR' world.loc[world['name'] == 'Greenland', 'iso_a3'] = 'GL' world.loc[world['name'] == 'Somaliland', 'iso_a3'] = 'SOM' world.loc[world['name'] == 'N. Cyprus','iso_a3'] = 'NCY' world.loc[world['name'] == 'Kosovo', 'iso_a3'] = 'RKS' Copy
documents.s: How to load add missing values to a data frame

documents.t: It's is possible to load tables from internet pages, e.g. from Wikipedia. In many cases, there are several tables on the page, some of them not directly visible to the user, so you might have to adjust which one you actually need. In the presented example, we load a table that holds countries and the official scripts used in it: Alphabet_URL = 'https://www.key-shortcut.com/en/writing-systems/world-map-of-alphabets-scripts' alpha_df = pd.read_html(Alphabet_URL)[2] #on this page, this is the 2nd table Copy
documents.s: How to load tables from the internet to a data frame

documents.t: Jupyter Notebook (formerly IPython Notebooks) is a web-based interactive computational environment for creating notebook documents. Notebook documents are used for literate programming, a method of writing computer programs. Modular notebooks may connect to a variety of computational back ends, called "kernels". Notebook interfaces are widely used for statistics, data science, machine learning, and computer algebra. source_notebook Jupyter Notebook can connect to many kernels to allow programming in different languages. A Jupyter kernel is a program responsible for handling various types of requests (code execution, code completions, inspection), and providing a reply. By default Jupyter Notebook ships with the IPython kernel. As of the 2.3 release (October 2014), there are 49 Jupyter-compatible kernels for many programming languages, including Python, R, Julia and Haskell. source_jupyter In this lecture, we will use the default Python kernel.
To follow along with this lecture you need requirements for dataframes (we will use the same data set as well) seaborn matplotlib jupyter

After having installed jupyter, you invoke it with jupyter notebook Copy If it does not automatically open in your browser, look for the address in your terminal (it contains "localhost") and manually copy it into your browser. You may also have to create a new (python kernel) file, if it does not open automatically. To get aquainted with jupyter, let's just repeat the first steps as described in Dataframes-basics First, import pandas, then read in the .csv file and look at the top 5 lines: import pandas as pd vgs = pd.read_csv(''vgsales.csv') #the general code is df = pd.read_csv('data.csv') # returns the first 5 rows vgs.head(5) Copy Overall, all the methods used in Dataframes-basics can be nicely displayed using jupyter. But you can do even more to present and visualize your data and certain results.
documents.s: How to read Dataframes in jupyter

documents.t: Now let's re-create the excercises presented in Dataframes-basics using graph visualizations. 2.) Select the 10 Publishers with the most unique games published vgs.groupby('Publisher')['Name'].nunique().nlargest(10) Copy Using this dataframe, we create a bar chart displaying the same information: import seaborn as sn import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt sn.barplot(x= df.groupby('Publisher')['Name'].nunique().nlargest(10).index, # Put the indices of the 10 largest companies on the x-axis y=df.groupby('Publisher')['Name'].nunique().nlargest(10)) # Put the number of sold games of the 10 largest companies on the y-axis #These parameters are optional plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (5,5) # Set the figure size plt.xticks(rotation=90) # Rotate the labels on the x-axis plt.title('Number of unique games in 10 most frequent publishers', # Set title fontsize=15, fontweight='bold') plt.xlabel('Publishers') # Set x-axis label plt.ylabel("Number of games") # Set y-axis label plt.show() Copy 3.) Rank all Publishers by their total Global_Sales ranked = vgs.groupby('Publisher')['Global_Sales'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False) Copy To visualize this would be messy, so let's select only the top 10 publishers according to global sales: ranked = vgs.groupby('Publisher')['Global_Sales'].sum().sort_values(ascending=False).head(10) Copy sn.barplot(x= ranked.index, y= ranked) plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (5,5) plt.xticks(rotation=90) plt.title('Number of top 10 according to global sales', fontsize=15, fontweight='bold') plt.xlabel('Publishers') plt.ylabel("Number of global sales") plt.show() Copy ::: From here needs to be revised :::

Streamlit is an open-source Python library that makes it easy to create and share beautiful, custom web apps for machine learning and data science. source_streamlit. You may find many open-source apps written in streamlit such as e.g. the following NLP apps: a demo of an spacy NLP pipeline or an analysis of the game of thrones characters.

To follow along with this lecture you need streamlit pandas geopandas regex folium google-transliteration-api Or just download the requirements.txt from the corresponding project and execute pip install -r requirements.txt Copy You can install some extra transliteration libraries if you want to implement some more scripts: aksharamukha transliterate

In this lecture, we will built an app that shows transliterations from latin to other scripts on a world map (showing the corresponding transliteration of the name at the place where the script is used). The choice of scripts is based on the availability of the transliteration.
documents.s: Step-by-step guide to our transliteration app

documents.t: Having installed streamlit, you need to write the corresponding python programme (which you can do in your favorite IDE or text editor). We create the file "translitName.py" and start with importing streamlit and adding a title to the app: import streamlit as st st.title('Script your name') Copy Now we can invoke it with : streamlit run translitName.py Copy As your command line will tell you, you can now open your streamlit app in your browser at ``http://localhost:8502´´.
Now we want to read in the user input: user_input = st.text_input("Put your name here in latin script") Copy
documents.s: How to load text in streamlit

documents.t: folium is a python library that can be used with streamlit. It makes it easy to visualize data that’s been manipulated in Python on an interactive leaflet map. It enables both the binding of data to a map for choropleth visualizations as well as passing rich vector/raster/HTML visualizations as markers on the map. folium source To visualize the map with transliterated texts, you need the following code: #create map m = merge.explore( legend=False, tiles='StamenWatercolor', color=merge['Script'].apply(lambda x: colors_scripts[x]), tooltip=['name','Script','Writing system','Transliteration']) #max_bounds=True, #width=500) #height=1000, #location=[13.406,170.110], #zoom_start=1) #create elements class DivIcon(MacroElement): def __init__(self, html='', size=(30,30), anchor=(0,0), style=''): #def __init__(self, html='', style=''): """TODO : docstring here""" super(DivIcon, self).__init__() self._name = 'DivIcon' self.size = size self.anchor = anchor self.html = html self.style = style self._template = Template(u""" {% macro header(this, kwargs) %} <style> .{{this.get_name()}} { {{this.style}} } </style> {% endmacro %} {% macro script(this, kwargs) %} var {{this.get_name()}} = L.divIcon({ className: '{{this.get_name()}}', iconSize: [{{ this.size[0] }},{{ this.size[1] }}], iconAnchor: [{{ this.anchor[0] }},{{ this.anchor[1] }}], html : "{{this.html}}", }); {{this._parent.get_name()}}.setIcon({{this.get_name()}}); {% endmacro %} """) #put in Scripts for i in range(len(merge)): fontpath = str('fonts/'+str(fonts_scripts[merge.Script[i]])) if merge.ShowTransliteration[i]==True: folium.map.Marker([float(merge.latitude[i]), float(merge.longitude[i])],icon=DivIcon( size=(150,36), anchor=(150,12), html=transliteration_scripts[merge.Script[i]].capitalize(), style=""" font-size:14px; background-color: transparent; border-color: transparent; text-align: right; """ ) ).add_to(m) folium.map.Marker( [float(merge.latitude[i]), float(merge.longitude[i])], icon=DivIcon( size=(150,36), anchor=(150,0), html=merge.Script[i].capitalize(), style=""" font-size:10px; background-color: transparent; border-color: transparent; text-align: right; """ ) ).add_to(m) folium_static(m) Copy
documents.s: How to display a map using folium

documents.t: ::: From here needs to be revised :::
documents.s: How to run the Streamlit app publically

documents.t: Docker is a set of platform as a service (PaaS) products that use OS-level virtualization to deliver software in packages called containers. Containers are isolated from one another and bundle their own software, libraries and configuration files; they can communicate with each other through well-defined channels. Docker can package an application and its dependencies in a virtual container that can run on any Linux, Windows, or macOS computer. This enables the application to run in a variety of locations, such as on-premises, in public or private cloud. Because all of the containers share the services of a single operating system kernel, they use fewer resources than virtual machines. source

Germany's National Meteorological Service, the Deutscher Wetterdienst (DWD), is responsible for meeting meteorological requirements arising from all areas of economy and society in Germany.source They make their data publically available. We will use their data in this lecture.

To follow along with this lecture you need Docker python pandas The service of DWD, wetterdienst, can be used by either installing it on your workstation or within a Docker container. In this lecture we will do the latter, using the smaller of the two Docker image flavors "standard" (instead of "full") $ docker run -ti ghcr.io/earthobservations/wetterdienst-standard Copy To be able to read the data, one needs to import pandas and the library of wetterdienst import wetterdienst from wetterdienst.provider.dwd.observation import DwdObservationRequest import pandas as pd ´´´ ### Send requests Now one can send requests and get dataframes as feedback, e.g. ```cmd request = DwdObservationRequest(parameter=["climate_summary"], resolution="daily", start_date="1990-01-01", end_date="2020-01-01", tidy=True, humanize=True, si_units=True).filter_by_station_id(station_id=(1048, 4411)) ´´´ request is a dataframe, the information contenr of which can be seen in the following way: Copy request.df ´´´ returns station_id from_date to_date height latitude longitude name state 209 01048 1934-01-01 00:00:00+00:00 2021-11-28 00:00:00+00:00 228.0 51.1278 13.7543 Dresden-Klotzsche Sachsen 818 04411 1979-12-01 00:00:00+00:00 2021-11-28 00:00:00+00:00 155.0 49.9195 8.9671 Schaafheim-Schlierbach Hessen ### Send requests ::: No info on temperature; played around with parameter="air_temperature"; but no results so far. https://wetterdienst.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage/explorer.html gives at least some overview which parameters (in combination with others) have a result at all. No examples or docu found to use air/soil temperature to e.g. show global warming ::: Copy
You can provide a downloadable resource by using DownloadButton or DownloadLink

import {DownloadLink} from '@theme/Download'; The DownloadLink <DownloadLink path="/datasets/vgsales.csv" text="does not"/> break the text flow. Copy The DownloadLink does not break the text flow. danger The path root is in /static and has to start with a backslash. datasets/vgsales.csv or ./datasets/vgslaes.csv will not be accepted!

Optional Arguments are text : the text inside the link or button name : the name of the downloaded file import {DownloadButton} from '@theme/Download'; <DownloadButton path="/datasets/vgsales.csv" text="example dataset" name="dataset.csv"/> Copy example dataset info if you provide a name you have to include the file extension

let x = 1+1 function increment(n){ return n+1 } Copy x = 1+1 def increment(n): return n+1 Copy note if no language is specified in markdown or the language is not supported the codeblock renders as usual x = 1+1 def increment(n): return n+1 Copy
a new language specific color can be added with just two css rules .prism-code.language-css{--language-color: pink} .prism-code.language-css::after{content: "css"} Copy
